text: Hi. Are there any RxJava experts. I want to build a REST client. But before every http call the app should check if some data is available and if not pause the request until the needed data is loaded via http call. is there a possibility to easily handle this with all requests like a compose function to subscribeOn „<http://Schedulers.io|Schedulers.io>() and observeOn „AndroidSchedulers.mainThread()“?
<@U0552KSRK> thanks for the heads-up. That's really a big attack vector for injecting malicious code into _many_ apps at once.
Do you know if Google is having any plans on preventing such "mistakes" in future?
<@U08KKN48P> that's the typical use case for `flatMap()` where you flat-map the result of the first request operation to generate another request.

<@U2DJCQGKW|lam> has joined the channel
Also RxJava related. How to observe events of an observable on a single, dedicated background thread per subscription?
I need to ensure order of events, but every subscriber should have its own thread for performance.
It seems the default RxJava schedulers won't allow this?
Any ideas? :stuck_out_tongue:
Shedculer.newThread?
As far as I understand this will create a new thread for every event.
Meaning it won't guarantee the order of events received by the subscriber.
Essentially, I guess what I want is a new-thread version of `Schedulers.trampoline()` where a thread is created at subscription time, and used for dispatching a queue until unsubscribing.
Isn't there a queue based scheduler?
I guess there is, yeah. It's probably the `EventDispatchScheduler` or something like that...
digging into the API a bit deeper
Yeah I don’t think you can do this with threads since they are by their very nature *asynchronous*
Uhm, but that's the whole idea of Rx
Yeah, sorry I may have just misread :smile:
No problem :slightly_smiling_face: One would think that Rx makes threading simpler :smile:
ok back on mac, maybe use a custom executor for that usecase?
Oh well
There's the `HandlerScheduler`
That could be the solution I'm looking for!

text:
Seems it uses a special action
```
          Intent { act=com.android.finsky.APP_DETAILS_DIALOG cat=[android.intent.category.DEFAULT] pkg=com.android.vending cmp=com.android.vending/com.google.android.finsky.activities.InlineAppDetailsDialog (has extras) }
```
yeah looks like internal feature only
Found that online <https://github.com/DroidDemos/REMIUI/blob/48d65600a1b04931a510e1f036e58356af1531c0/googleplay/com/google/android/finsky/activities/InlineAppDetailsDialog.java>

attachments.title: DroidDemos/REMIUI
attachments.text: Contribute to REMIUI development by creating an account on GitHub.

text: It's essentially the dialog activity they are calling
(don't ask me where these sources come from o_O)

You can call that dialog using this on your device
```
am start -a com.android.finsky.APP_DETAILS_DIALOG -c android.intent.category.DEFAULT -e docid com.ted.android com.android.vending/com.google.android.finsky.activities.InlineAppDetailsDialog
```
This would open the dialog for `com.ted.android`
But you walk into their security trap, printing a warning that you're an untrustred source
That should do the trick!
I'm creating a fresh thread having a looper, creating a scheduler based on that, and shutting the thread down on unsubscribe.
This will ensure events are dispatched on a new thread per subscriber, and the subscriber still receives events in order.
Fingers crossed :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
